sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_2:
To find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix, we can use the following formula:

det(A) = a(ei − fh) − b(di − fg) + c(dh − eg)

where a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, and i are the elements of the matrix:

A = \begin{bmatrix}
a & b & c \\
d & e & f \\
g & h & i
\end{bmatrix}

In this case, the matrix A is:

A = \begin{bmatrix}
2 & 5 & 1 \\
3 & 2 & 6 \\
1 & 0 & 4
\end{bmatrix}

So, the determinant of A is:

det(A) = 2(2*4 - 6*0) - 5(3*4 - 6*1) + 1(3*0 - 2*1)
det(A) = 2(8 - 0) - 5(12 - 6) + 1(0 - 2)
det(A) = 2(8) - 5(6) - 1(2)
det(A) = 16 - 30 - 2
det(A) = -14

Therefore, the determinant of the given matrix A is -14.
